I'm a bit ambivalent on this, ideally it wouldn't matters so much what version of Python is used in the first place *if* it's more recent than the minimum.
@MarcoFalke I got rid of the Github links and switched to the more aesthetic version ordering.

@laanwj I agree with that. The problem is that Python doesn't have a way to enforce backwards compatibility in any given script file. That's why I added PyEnv support in #14884 which prevents us from accidentally using Python > 3.4 syntax. The only reason for the change here is that otherwise PyEnv breaks.\n\nMaybe someone knows another approach for `configure.ac` to find the correct python exec

There shouldn't be any difference in what python version `make check` runs, since all supported versions should work equally. Also, the gitian builds use the bionic python3 version, which wouldn't change with that patch. I don't see any risk in this patch.\n\nutACK 0890339fb337de7690d501a5436657a9d996e5a7

> I don't know if there are any systems where python3 doesn't point to the most recently installed version. 

IIRC there are some systems which don't have `python3` nor `python` *at all*, and only versioned named (BSDs maybe?). Though I don't remember the exact history of that line I'm fairly sure it's like this for a good reason.

@laanwj override with what though? Another autodetect specifically for this purpose?

I'd prefer not using auto-detect at all in that case, when you know what exact Python executable you want to use. You can pass what version you want to configure.\n\nMy real point here is that I don't like treating Python 3.4 specially in auto-detection just because it happens to be used in our tests right now. Say, we bump that Python version later and then this needs to be changed again, it's

We don't know which Python executable to use. It's either `python` or `python3`, somewhere in `$PATH`, when using PyEnv.\n\nAnother approach could be to not use `python3.4` style executables, unless `python3` and `python` return a version that's unacceptably old. I don't know how to configure that though.

> Say, we bump that Python version later and then this needs to be changed again, it's easy to forget.\n\nThe python3.4 would need to be removed either way. At least with this change it is no longer so easy to forget.

Could you reorder those, such that python3.4 is merely the first to look for? Unless you are certain that there is a python3 alias on all systems. (Otherwise it would fall back to `python`, which commonly means `python2`)
Done. That indeed seems safer, and still works with PyEnv.

I'd prefer not to link to github issues unless necessary to keep the source code "self contained" as possible.\n\nI guess you could delete this comment altogether, since we added `doc/dependencies.md` in the meantime.
